bibl.title: Letter from Sidney Howard to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 21, 1928

div1.p: Howard inquires about Walter Reed's character for his play “Yellow Jack.“

div1.head: Letter from Sidney Howard to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 21, 1928

opener.dateline:
SIDNEY HOWARD
157 EAST 62ND STREET
NEW YORK CITY
February 21st, 1928.

div1.p:
I have a letter this morning from
Colonel Siler which tells me that you will not mind talking
to me about this play of mine in which Major Reed is such
an important character. I have come to you for your help,
in spite of my reluctance to trouble you, because I need
to know so much more than I have so far been able to
learn about Major Reed as a person. All the time that I
have been working on the manuscript and thinking about it
I have been haunted by that passage which both Paul de Kruif
and Mark Sullivan quote from his New Year's Eve letter to
you. Those are words which must be spoken in the play.
I am hoping that you will have other letters from which you
will allow me to quote because every such quotation will
bring the play character nearer to the real and wonderful
life of the original. You are most kind to offer to cooperate
with Paul and me. I can only assure you that we shall do
our utmost to make “Yellowjack” into a play of which you
will, at least, not be ashamed. I have very much the feeling
that it is the kind of play which ought to be written and
acted these days.

I am coming down to Washington on Sunday, the twenty-sixth
and I shall stop in the Mayflower. Perhaps you will let me
come to call on you Sunday evening if you are free. May I
look for a word from you at the hotel when I arrive there?
div1.closer: Most Sincerely Yours, Sidney Howard. Mrs. Walter Reed.
